posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
When I run our flywheels using REV they work perfectly getting to exactly the desired RPM in no time, but when I use our code (in which we’re using the CANSparkMAX PidController) the flywheels go at like half the speed.

Why might this be?

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Can you share a link to your code? And maybe a screenshot of it working in the REV hardware client?

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
Final-Development

Contribute to SFUnity/Quake development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked: The graph is just they overshoot a little and then settle at our target (right now 4000rpm). When I run the code both REV client and AdvantageScope w/ values from the NEO relative encoders read an RPM of around 2000.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226

link_counts.title: SPARK-MAX-Examples/Java/Velocity Closed Loop Control/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java at b865e5fa644bc859769c7a6130b7101176aec6d5 · REVrobotics/SPARK-MAX-Examples · GitHub

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked: But that still doesn’t explain the problem, right? Because if the PID constants were wrong then the flywheels either wouldn’t spin or would oscillate like crazy. Instead they precisely go to half the desired speed

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Not sure, but in the process of hard coding your PID , you might find out the underlying issue. It’s good practice anyways

posts.name: Basel Alghanem
posts.cooked:
Avi:

When I run the code both REV client and AdvantageScope w/ values from the NEO relative encoders read an RPM of around 2000.

Is there a way for you to see the reference (aka the target)? Simplest explanation would be a different target rpm is getting set than you expected

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
The sparkpidcontroller doesn’t have a getSetpoint() method. These desiredSpeed entries though are accurate, so I’m pretty sure it’s at the right setpoint. Screenshot 2024-03-07 at 11.31.00 AM 1102×190 43.1 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-07 at 11.31.00 AM 1102×190 43.1 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-07 at 11.31.00 AM 1102×190 43.1 KB

posts.name: Basel Alghanem
posts.cooked:
I think I agree unless it’s somehow fighting intakeNote which also sets that setpoint.

Setpoint difference just feels like the most obvious possible way it could be failing, could easily be something more subtle.
